posts.body:
Types and Techniques of Propaganda

Propaganda is not anything that attempts to convey a message or even anything that attempts to persuade. Propaganda in its modern sense must meet a certain definition. Propaganda uses media as a vehicle for persuasion. It targets emotions, attitudes, and opinions through one-sided messages.

Propaganda can often be identified by some of its strategies. It targets strong emotions and attacks opponents and it simplifies information as a way to direct people’s thinking. Common techniques of propaganda include name-calling opponents, “bandwagoning”, (two types: join the crowd and inevitable victory), and glittering generalities (strong positive words without any foundation for them), as well as a number of logical fallacies.

Propaganda is often separated into three types according to its publishing style. ‘White propaganda’ is open about its source and intent; an advertisement to join the Armed Forces is an example. 'Gray propaganda’ does not disclose its source; TikTok influencers selling products without labeling the videos as ads would count. 'Black propaganda’ is designed to look like it comes from the ideological enemy of the people who actually created it. The Church of Scientology occasionally uses this. Their book Brain-Washing (1955) was allegedly written by Soviet secret police chief Beria but in actuality by Hubbard, to connect certain unfavorable practices to Communism during the Red Scare. False flag operations would work the same way.

Many groups will use a combination. Consider an issue an attempt to find one of each of the three types about it. For example, anti-vaccination:

  1. White propaganda: anti-vax groups openly campaigning against vaccination programs
  2. Gray propaganda: an anti-vaccine advocate, pretending to be on the fence, continually brings up doubts and fears to others
  3. Black propaganda: an anti-vax publication circulates false or misleading 'evidence’ that Anthony Fauci said vaccines are useless

For extra credit, do this for an issue that you agree with. Remember, not everyone in your camp is always arguing in good faith.

posts.summary: The Real World vs. The World in Propaganda
posts.body:
The Real World vs. The World in Propaganda

Modern propaganda typically functions via emotional manipulation. Certain emotional states are better for manipulating the target, so propaganda will seek to make you feel two different ways–often at the same time. First, you must be scared of the world around you–fear is an excellent motivator. Second, you must have your ego stoked, to believe that you are correct and your actions are very important in stopping the thing causing you to feel afraid. A propagandist will create a world that makes you feel both scared and able to stop being scared quickly.

In the world of propaganda, each effect has one cause, which can be clearly seen. Problems are caused by individuals acting poorly. These individuals tend to be minorities who have been scapegoated or a single person in power who is being scapegoated by other people in power trying to keep eyes off themselves. In addition, people are easy to figure out and have a singular motive. In the world of propaganda, solutions to problems are easy to do and achieve their goal perfectly. They tend to be things that can be done a single time, without repeated effort, like buying something, “raising awareness”, or a single personal action. Ideally, you go most of your life unconcerned about anything except during a crisis, which causes fear and the desired action, before returning to the comfortable status quo.

In the real world, multiple interconnected causes lead to an effect, which themselves are causes for yet more effects. Problems are the result of self-sustaining systems of power, within which people are complex actors with many, sometimes internally contradictory goals. Solutions to problems are complex and have many parts, and these solutions always have drawbacks. They typically require large-scale systemic change, such as policy efforts or a reassessment of personal values. A person in this world should spend their entire life considering the far-reaching impacts of normal actions and focus on long-term trends rather than starting and stopping to care about issues during a sudden crisis, without feeling unduly scared or stress by these constant considerations.

Consider these in the specific example of sexual harassment in the entertainment industry, like the #MeToo movement. Though the #MeToo movement was started by Tamara Burke in 2006, it became noticeably more influential in late 2017 after several high-level accusations of sexual abuse perpetrated by film producer Harvey Weinstein. Though the accusations were covered up for many years, they eventually became too big to ignore, potentially indicting many of Weinstein’s friends who had enabled his abuse. Although discussion touched and the widespread culture of sexual abuse in Hollywood and the harms that fell on people who reported them, any actual focus was kept strictly to Weinstein and his accusers, precluding any actual widespread change of the culture and protecting other powerful abusers who are certainly still in the industry.

In this way, the entertainment system protected itself. It let Weinstein take the fall as an individual for what essentially every actor and actress agreed was a widespread systemic problem. It treated Weinstein as the sole problem and as a sudden crisis that had to be resolved, preventing any further solutions from causing a lasting change that might have disrupted the stability of power in Hollywood once he was convicted.

On your own, consider how these principles apply to other social problems you’ve seen or experienced. Think about energy companies proposing individual solutions to environmental issues to shift blame from their industrial processes. Consider how it benefits them, after an incident of racially-motivated police brutality, for the police administration to blame “one bad apple” and then do nothing to remove said bad apple. Think about fast fashion companies selling “vegan leather” as an environmentally friendly alternative that is worse for the environment than normal leather, even though they also linen clothes.

posts.summary: What exactly happened to cause you to have a weeks worth of posts dedicated to propaganda?
posts.question: What exactly happened to cause you to have a weeks worth of posts dedicated to propaganda?
posts.answer:
Good question!

This is not in response to any particular incident, but rather a general trend of increasingly hidden propaganda, lack of critical thinking regarding media, and even in those who are properly critical simply not knowing what to do with propaganda once they’ve found it.

It’s also because people seem to think propaganda is something “other people” (often the Chinese) do, or something that ended after WWII or the Cold War. People seem to think propaganda must be from governments. People seem to think anything on ‘their side’ politically cannot be propaganda. People seem to think something has to be false to be propaganda. These all need to be debunked.

As a blog focused on history, a LOT of history (and pseudohistory) is used, twisted, or covered up in the name of propaganda. In fact, history education is one of the propagandists’ most useful tools! Anything that teaches history without discussing this is giving, at most, half an education. It quickly becomes “a little knowledge is a dangerous thing”.

I started planning and drafting this well before the death of Queen Elizabeth II, but the media’s response to it will undoubtedly feature. The propaganda regarding it is everywhere, and it will make for great examples and descriptions of trends and tendencies.

posts.body:
Introduction to Propaganda

Propaganda is any communication used to influence people to push an agenda. It’s typically political in nature, but can be religious, social, economic, and especially military.

In modern English contexts, propaganda has a manipulative and negative connotation, and implies strong bias, deliberate spread of misinformation, and manipulation of apparently unrelated media. However, historically and in equivalent non-English words, it was a neutral word.

Propaganda is a Latin word from the same root as ‘to propagate’ (like of plants). It comes from an administrative body of the Catholic-Church, the Congregatio de Propaganda Fide, created in 1622 as part of the Counter-Reformation. It was supposed to “propagate” Catholicism in non-Catholic countries.

Examples of propaganda predate the word. One of the earliest is a political propaganda piece, the Behistun Inscription in what is now Iran. It included the same text in three languages, crucial to deciphering cuneiform–it is ‘to cuneiform what the Rosetta Stone is to Egyptian hieroglyphs’. THe Behistun Inscription was authored by ruler Darius I of the Achaemenid Persian Empire, and includes a brief autobiography and a description of himself fighting nineteen battles to put down rebellions and false kings, succeeding due to the grace of Ahura Mazda (the creator deity of Zoroastrianism). It would have been easily accessible to common people, as it was above an ancient road connecting two important cities.

It was in the 20th century, alongside the quick development of media and communication, that propaganda changed. This was mostly related to the war efforts–the First World War and onwards–and it is likewise during this time that the word ‘propaganda’ took on its negative connotation.

Propaganda has existed for as long as humans have had opinions. A smarter and informed person should assume everything they read, watch, listen to, and see was created by someone attempting to achieve some goal. Part of your duty is to be aware of this. If something seems self-evident and completely non-manipulative to you, that likely means that the propaganda has gotten past your mental firewall–take a step back and think it through again! Especially on things you agree with. Propaganda is not a tool of the ‘bad guys’, and acting like it is will allow you to miss and fail to engage critically with a lot of propaganda you come into contact with.

posts.summary: In the upcoming weeks, this blog will be running a series on propaganda. Recognizing and understanding propaganda is important...
posts.body:
In the upcoming weeks, this blog will be running a series on propaganda. Recognizing and understanding propaganda is important in what history we look at, how we look at it, and how we apply it to the present. Recognizing and understanding propaganda is also necessary to understand current events, news, and media.

More than anything, I hope this series will be a discussion rather than a lecture. Please respond! Ask questions, especially stupid questions (anon will be on), add your own examples or points, recommend reading.



POSTS
Introduction to Propaganda
The Real World vs. The World in Propaganda
Types and Techniques of Propaganda
Common Cognitive Biases in Propaganda
Common Cognitive Biases in Propaganda Part II
Common Fallacies in Propaganda
Common Fallacies in Propaganda Part II

QUESTIONS
“What exactly happened to cause you to have a weeks worth of posts dedicated to propaganda?” from anonymous

posts.body:
On This Day In History

September 14th, 2015: LIGO and Virgo make the first observation of gravitational waves (announced Feb. 11, 2016 after confirmation).

Gravitational waves had been indirectly inferred previously, but this waveform was the first direct proof of their existence. This observation confirmed the final undetected prediction of general relativity (which, when proposed by Einstein one hundred years previously, though impossible. He thought the waves were so small they could never be detected).

posts.body:
Elizabeth Mary of House Windsor

HER LIFE

Elizabeth II, Queen of the United Kingdom, Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, The Bahamas, Belize, Canada, Grenada, Jamaica, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Solomon Islands, and Tuvalu (all totalling about 151 million people) was perhaps the most known women in the world.

Elizabeth (1926-2022) was the first child of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. She and her sister, Margaret, were raised in the castle and privately educated, and were kept out of public eye for much of their childhood.

During World War II she began undertaking public duties, starting with making radio addresses and public appearances. She was appointed colonel of the Grenadier Guards in 1943 and honorary second subaltern of the Auxiliary Territorial Service in 1945. She was trained to work on car engines, though I cannot find any evidence that she performed any services beneficial to the war effort.

Elizabeth married Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark (self-styled Philip Mountbatten to emphasize his British heritage, he would renounce his Greek and Danish titles and convert to Anglicanism) in 1947, when she was 21 and he was 26, though they had met thirteen years previously. Philip was her second cousin once removed.

As her father’s health declined in 1951, Elizabeth increasingly took center stage at public events. In 1952, following her father’s death, she was proclaimed queen. From the end of WWII and around 1960, the globe saw the widespread decolonization from imperial powers such as Great Britain, most of which Elizabeth oversaw. Throughout her extensive rule, public favor on the Royal Family, and monarchy in general, decreased. Her family had a number of scandals, mostly with regards to love and marriages. Increased knowledge of the financial impacts of the Royal Family also caused increased Republican attitude, and a storm of sudden emergencies such as the climate crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and Brexit increased public distrust of governmental authority.

Reigning for over 70 years, Elizabeth II was the longest reigning British monarch in history and the second-longest reign of any monarch in history (following Louis XIV of France and Navarre, who reigned just over 72 years in the 17th and 18th centuries). She reigned alongside 15 prime ministers.

THE ROLE OF THE CROWN

The United Kingdom monarchy is a constitutional monarchy now headed by Charles III, her son. Their role in government is severely limited, and their duties are largely ceremonial, representational, and diplomatic. The elected Parliament is the functional head of UK government.

In reality, British royalty and nobility have an undue influence of domestic and international politics. The bicameral Parliament has two houses, the House Lords containing members of the Church of England and hereditary peers (dukes, marquesses, earls, viscounts, barons. There are 808 hereditary peers in the United Kingdom).

The monarch, such as Elizabeth II or Charles III, has the role of Crown-in-Parliament (Queen-in-Parliament or King-in-Parliament) which acts with the advice and consent of the Parliament. The monarch does have the power to veto or refuse to sign laws passed by Parliament (withholding royal assent), remove the elected Prime Minister from power, or dissolve Parliament entirely.

In the judicial government, the monarch appoints the Justices of the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom, as well as the power to change the number of judges. The monarch also appoints most high offices of the state, is commander-in-chief of all military branches, ratifies treaties, and declares war.

Religiously, the monarch is the Head of the Church of England and appoints all bishops and archbishops,

The monarch also has significant political power in Commonwealth Nations. In Canada, for example, the appointed Governor General (currently Mary Simon, Inuit) has the power to veto any bill, call and dissolve Parliament, can offer judicial immunity and pardon, and can refuse the appointment of the Canadian Prime Minister. Much of foreign affairs, everything from wars, alliances, ambassadors, and even issuing passports, are powers of the Crown.

Much of political stability of the United Kingdom and the 14 Commonwealth Nations rests under the assumption that the monarch will never actually use any of the powers they have. Doing so would cause a Constitutional crisis and likely end with the immediate arrest of said monarch (most consider it a fair assumption the guard would side with Parliament over the Crown despite the Crown being in the legal right).

FACTS ABOUT THE ROYAL FAMILY

The Royal Family now includes 9 people (immediate family of King Charles III who carry out royal duties full time). The heir apparent to the throne in Prince William, Duke of Cornwall and Cambridge (b. 1982).

The monarch is not required to pay income tax, capital gains tax, or inheritance tax.

Either the Crown itself of members of the Royal Family own 24 royal residences.

In 2021, the Royal Family cost the British taxpayers 102.4million pounds.

The Royal Wedding of 2018 between Prince Harry and Meghan Markle cost about 34million pounds, of which 94% was paid from taxes.

In addition to using government money for personal use, the Royal Family has several streams of income, including the 86-million pound Sovereign Grant, millions of pounds from the Duchies of Cornwall and Lancaster, and other assets

The Crown holds hundreds of thousands of works of art, much of which is in private residencies or not on display.

The monarch is the only person in all of Scotland not required to use renewable energy in the construction of pipelines to heat buildings, after intense lobbying from the Crown’s lawyers.

The monarch, such as Elizabeth II or Charles III, has the role of Crown-in-Parliament (Queen-in-Parliament or King-in-Parliament) which acts with the advice and consent of the Parliament. The monarch does have the power to veto or refuse to sign laws passed by Parliament (withholding royal assent), remove the elected Prime Minister from power, or dissolve Parliament entirely.

In the judicial government, the monarch appoints the Justices of the Supreme Court of the United Kingdom, as well as the power to change the number of judges. The monarch also appoints most high offices of the state, is commander-in-chief of all military branches, ratifies treaties, and declares war.

Religiously, the monarch is the Head of the Church of England and appoints all bishops and archbishops,

The monarch also has significant political power in Commonwealth Nations. In Canada, for example, the appointed Governor General (currently Mary Simon, Inuit) has the power to veto any bill, call and dissolve Parliament, can offer judicial immunity and pardon, and can refuse the appointment of the Canadian Prime Minister. Much of foreign affairs, everything from wars, alliances, ambassadors, and even issuing passports, are powers of the Crown.

Much of political stability of the United Kingdom and the 14 Commonwealth Nations rests under the assumption that the monarch will never actually use any of the powers they have. Doing so would cause a Constitutional crisis and likely end with the immediate arrest of said monarch (most consider it a fair assumption the guard would side with Parliament over the Crown despite the Crown being in the legal right).

FACTS ABOUT THE ROYAL FAMILY

The Royal Family now includes 9 people (immediate family of King Charles III who carry out royal duties full time). The heir apparent to the throne in Prince William, Duke of Cornwall and Cambridge (b. 1982).

The monarch is not required to pay income tax, capital gains tax, or inheritance tax.

Either the Crown itself of members of the Royal Family own 24 royal residences.

In 2021, the Royal Family cost the British taxpayers 102.4million pounds.

The Royal Wedding of 2018 between Prince Harry and Meghan Markle cost about 34million pounds, of which 94% was paid from taxes.

In addition to using government money for personal use, the Royal Family has several streams of income, including the 86-million pound Sovereign Grant, millions of pounds from the Duchies of Cornwall and Lancaster, and other assets

The Crown holds hundreds of thousands of works of art, much of which is in private residencies or not on display.

The monarch is the only person in all of Scotland not required to use renewable energy in the construction of pipelines to heat buildings, after intense lobbying from the Crown’s lawyers.
trail.content:
Elizabeth Mary of House Windsor

HER LIFE

Elizabeth II, Queen of the United Kingdom, Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, The Bahamas, Belize, Canada, Grenada, Jamaica, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Solomon Islands, and Tuvalu (all totalling about 151 million people) was perhaps the most known women in the world.

Elizabeth (1926-2022) was the first child of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. She and her sister, Margaret, were raised in the castle and privately educated, and were kept out of public eye for much of their childhood.

During World War II she began undertaking public duties, starting with making radio addresses and public appearances. She was appointed colonel of the Grenadier Guards in 1943 and honorary second subaltern of the Auxiliary Territorial Service in 1945. She was trained to work on car engines, though I cannot find any evidence that she performed any services beneficial to the war effort.

Elizabeth married Prince Philip of Greece and Denmark (self-styled Philip Mountbatten to emphasize his British heritage, he would renounce his Greek and Danish titles and convert to Anglicanism) in 1947, when she was 21 and he was 26, though they had met thirteen years previously. Philip was her second cousin once removed.

As her father’s health declined in 1951, Elizabeth increasingly took center stage at public events. In 1952, following her father’s death, she was proclaimed queen. From the end of WWII and around 1960, the globe saw the widespread decolonization from imperial powers such as Great Britain, most of which Elizabeth oversaw. Throughout her extensive rule, public favor on the Royal Family, and monarchy in general, decreased. Her family had a number of scandals, mostly with regards to love and marriages. Increased knowledge of the financial impacts of the Royal Family also caused increased Republican attitude, and a storm of sudden emergencies such as the climate crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and Brexit increased public distrust of governmental authority.

Reigning for over 70 years, Elizabeth II was the longest reigning British monarch in history and the second-longest reign of any monarch in history (following Louis XIV of France and Navarre, who reigned just over 72 years in the 17th and 18th centuries). She reigned alongside 15 prime ministers.

THE ROLE OF THE CROWN

The United Kingdom monarchy is a constitutional monarchy now headed by Charles III, her son. Their role in government is severely limited, and their duties are largely ceremonial, representational, and diplomatic. The elected Parliament is the functional head of UK government.

In reality, British royalty and nobility have an undue influence of domestic and international politics. posts.body:
On This Day In History

August 28th, 1955: Emmett Till is lynched.

A Black 14-year-old accused of whistling at (or flirting with, or putting his hand around the waist of) a White woman, he was abducted, tortured, and murdered by two men who were not punished. The description propelled Till, posthumously, into the forefront of the American Civil Rights Movement.

The men, Roy Bryant and J.W. Milam, were never convicted and publically told their story, selling it for $4,000.

The woman, Carolyn Bryant, has also not faced justice. On August 10th, 2022, a grand jury declined to indict her.

Claims that Carolyn Bryant recanted her entire story are incomplete and misleading–she now says she cannot remember the exact details, and she apparently said some of her story was false during an untaped portion of an otherwise taped interview.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

August 27th, 865: Abu Bakr al-Razi, one of the most important figures of medical history, is born.

A Persian polymath and proponent of experimental medicine, he is known for studying and treating smallpox, as the father of pediatrics, and a pioneer of obstetrics and ophthalmology. He is the first known human to recognize the reaction of the eye’s pupil to light. He wrote extensively on many medical topics, including medical ethics, and his works were massively influential in medical education across Europe.

1st World Romani Congress

The first World Romani Congress was organized in 1971 in Orpington near London, England, United Kingdom, funded in part by the World Council of Churches and the Government of India. It was attended by 23 representatives from nine nations (Czechoslovakia, Finland, Norway, France, Great Britain, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Spain and Yugoslavia) and observers from Belgium, Canada, India and the United States.

On This Day In History

August 19th, 1782: The last major battle of the American Revolutionary War, the Battle of Blue Licks, occurs in what is now Kentucky. The Loyalists to the Crown triumph, alongside 300 Native American warriors

This battle occurred 10 months after the end of the war and the surrender of the English.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

August 16, 1946: Direct Action Day, or the 1946 Calcutta Killings. Large-scale violence between Muslims and Hindus in Kolkata, British India. More than 4,000 died and 100,000 were left homeless.

This, and other religious riots like it, were a major reason for the later Partition of India in 1947.
